Very-long-baseline interferometry (VLBI) is a type of astronomical interferometry used in Arctic astronomy. In LBI, it collects signals from digital radio sources, such as quasars, using multiple radio telescopes on Earth or in space. Thyou calculate the distance betwethe ice telescopes using the difference in the timing of the radio signal's arrival at the different telescopes. It allows for the simultaneous detection of mass by multiple radar telescopes, allowing for the use of a single large telescope the size of the minimum distance betwethe telescopes. The arithmetic incorporates the data received in the composite aerial, the time of arrival of the signal using a local atomic clock, such as a hydrogmeter. Later, the data is combined with other acoustic data that recorded the same radio signal, to produce the final image. The ratio of the accuracy that can be achieved using the measurement of the interference with the frequency of the observation. The LBI technology allows the distance betwethe telescopes to be much greater than the distance possible using traditional interference measurement, which requires the aerial to be routed by axle cables, waveguides, optical fibers, or any other form of electrical transport. Larger distances can be achieved at the LBI by using the shutter technology developed by Roger Jennings in the 1950s, which allows the LBI to produce images with much higher resolution. LBI techniques are being used to image distant cosmic magnetic field sources, track spacecraft, as well as other applications in astronomical measurement. However, because the LBI technology measures the time differences betwethe arrival of thermal waves to separate radios, it can also be used "in reverse fashion" to conduct studies on the rotation of the Earth, the motions of the tectonic plates with high accuracy (in the range of millimeters), and to conduct other studies on the science of the division of the Earth (Geodesy).

Cosmology (from the Ancient Greek: Κωνσταντίνος, meaning "world" and "philosophy" which means "study" in the sense of a lecture or a lecture and which is attached to most of the words referring to the science that is studying this subject). It's the science that studies the origin, creation, history, contents and evolution of the universe, and studies the vast structure of space, everything from matter and energy. And yet, despite its inherent interweaving with modern physics, its roots extend back to ancient times with philosophical, religious, and metaphysical treatments of the origin of the universe. The science of cosmology is a relatively new subfield of the natural sciences, but it addresses some of the oldest questions that humanity has asked, such as: Is the universe finite? Has it existed since time immemorial? If the answer is no, how did the universe emerge from existence? And will it ever end? Since ancient times, humans have sought to construct a conceptual framework of some kind to answer questions about the universe and their relationship to it. The first models for the study of cosmology were wizards, while most of the older attempts were based on forms of oscillation (the ratio of human traits to non-human beings). Some of these attempts have incorporated the idea that the physical world is governed by powerful, will-powered entities that can help or harm humanity. Others argued that the physical world itself was solid, but that a god or a goddess could control its course, in which case the flow of creational wisdom from the origins of the universe to the entities could be understood - in part - by human beings. The roots of modern science go back to ancient Greece. Of course, Greeks were gods and their myths, and many of them were derived from neighboring cultures. But aside from these traditional elements, the Greeks began to establish a system of principles of scientific research, and were the first to establish the relationship betwecause and effect, as they realized that the description of a documented phenomena and its interpretation could be writtin mathematical or geometric terms, rather than relying on the concept of abstraction.

India ' s climate is strongly influenced by Himalayas and Tharr deserts, both leading to seasonal winds. Four major climate groups are prevalent in India: humid tropical, dry tropical, subtropical wet and mountainous. India is a very diverse country, a term used for 17 countries with high biodiversity and many indigenous or endemic species. India is home to 8.6% of all types of mammals, 13.7% of species of birds, 7.9% of reptile species, 6% of species of amphibians, 12.2% of species of fish, and 6.0% of all types of flowering plants. One third of Indian plants are endemic. India also contains four of the 34 biodiversity focal points in the world, or areas showing significant habitat loss with a high endemic presence.b] India ' s forest cover is 701,673 km2 (270,917 m2), representing 21.35% of the country ' s total land area. It can be divided into broad categories of parachute density, or the proportion of forest area covered by the tree umbrella, a very dense forest of more than 70%, occupying 2.61% of the country ' s land area. It prevails in the humid tropical forest of the Andman Islands and the West and North-East Indian Gates. Modest-density forest, with density ranging from 40% to 70%, occupies 9.59 percent of the land area of India. Moderate pineal forests prevail in the Himalayan mountains, the harsh, wet-shura forests in eastern India, and the dry-sage wood forest in central and southern India.

Ion detectors were first sold in the United States in 1951; they were used in important industrial and commercial enterprises in the years that followed because of the large volume and high cost. In 1955, a high-temperature home detector was developed and the U.S. Atomic Energy Authority granted the first permit for the distribution of smoke detectors using radioactive materials in 1963. The first low-cost smoke detector developed by Duane Dewey Persal in 1965, is a battery-drivmachine that replaces and is easy to install. "SmokeGard 700" is a beehive, made of fire-resistant metal. The company began a major production of these devices in 1975. Studies in the 1960s determined that smoke detectors respond faster than heat detectors. The first one-stop smoke detectors invented in 1970 and announced in the coming year were an ionoscopic detector, operated by a nine-volt battery, at a rate of $125 and sold at a rate of hundreds of thousands per year, several technological developments that took place betwe1971 and 1976, including the replacement of the cold-drop tube with solid electronics, which significantly reduced the detection area and made it possible to control the life of the battery. An intergalactic star or a rogue star is a star that does not exist within a galaxy. Such rare stars move quickly and do not follow a star system together. These stars were the source of much debate in the scientific community during the late 1990s and are believed to be the result of the collision of galaxies, or the break-up of binary stars as they approach a black hole (most galaxies have a black hole in their center, attributed to a galaxy around them; the search showed that there is a black hole in our galaxy with a mass of 2 million solar blocks). The prevailing belief was that stars existed only in galaxies, but this idea was refuted in 1997 with the discovery of a rogue star. It was the first discovery in the conglomerate of virgin galaxies, now believed to be a trillion stars of this kind. The rogue stars are dealing with the problem of lost barion. Pariones, a category of subatomic particles such as protons and neutrons that form the nucleus of atoms in normal matter. Many theories of the formation and evolution of the universe address this dilemma and suggest that the paraiones should be more than those found by scientists. Although the way these stars emerge is still a mystery, the more common theory is that the collision of two or more galaxies can throw some stars out into empty space betwegalaxies. It is believed that these rogue stars may come from very small galaxies, because their gravity is weak and easy to escape. Another theory is that stars can come out of a galaxy because of a supermassive black hole in this case, a rogue star is associated with another star (a binary star), one of which is pulled into a black hole in the center of the galaxy, the other star moves close to the hole and thslips away from its appeal.

Pumps are classified according to the principle of work and the way in which liquid pressure is increased to two main types: dynamic Pumps are divided into two main types: dynamic Pumps continuously raise liquid pressure by converting the liquid's kinetic energy into pressure using the Shaft axis and the Impeller thruster or fan. This type of pump operates with the principle of Bernoli, which states that liquid pressure increases if it is less rapid, so these pumps first increase the fluid speed by using the fan or defense to obtain motor energy, and thconvert this kinetic energy into pressure by increasing the pump exit space or so-called volute. The increased output space reduces the speed of the liquid, which in turn increases the pressure as provided for in the Bernoulli principle. According to the design code No. 610 issued by the American Petroleum Institute (API 610), the design code adopted by most engineers and designers in the world, centrifuge pumps (Centrifugal Pumps) are divided into three subspecies: (Positive Displacement Pumps) which lifts the pressure of the liquid by restricting it to a fixed-sized place, forcing the liquid to escape from the pump exit because of the liquid (non-pressure) characteristic. One of the advantages of this type of pump is that high pressure can be obtained for liquids compared to the previous type. However, one of its most important shortcomings is its high operational cost due to the large number of mobile parts. The pressure generated by these pumps depends on the amount of displacement (Housing Size) and the speed of circulation of the pump. Safety valve on the Discharge pipe line must always be used in this type of pump to avoid a fracture of pipes due to high pressure and vibration caused by movement.

Christmas Day is celebrated as a major holiday and official holiday in most countries of the world, including in non-Christian majority countries. In some non-Christian regions such as Macao and Hong Kong, Christmas was adopted as an official holiday during the previous colonial rule, and in others Christmas was adopted as an official holiday because of the influence of Christian minorities or foreign cultural influences in the State. Countries such as Japan, where Christmas is very popular despite a relatively small number of Christians, have adopted many secular aspects of Christmas, such as gifts, decorations and the tradition of a Christmas tree. Among countries where Christmas is not an official holiday, Afghanistan includes Algeria, Bhutan, Libya, Maldives, Mauritania, North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Tajikistan, Tunisia, Turkmenistan and Yemen. While Christmas is not considered official or public, the following States give the jury the right to holiday, including Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Cambodia, China, Comoros, Iran, Israel, Japan, Kuwait, Laos, Mongolia, Morocco, the Sultanate of Oman, Pakistan, Qatar, Thailand, Turkey, Uzbekistan, the United Arab Emirates and Viet Nam. Christmas celebrations around the world can differ markedly, reflecting different cultural and national traditions. Among countries with strong Christian traditions, a variety of Christmas celebrations have evolved that include forms of regional and local cultures. In addition to the Christmas service of all churches, and the Christmas fast in Eastern Orthodox churches, Christmas celebration has many social manifestations and accompanying celebrations. Christmas and Christmas Eve is a festival in Lutheran churches, a binding sacred day in the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox Church and a major holiday in the English Church.

The judicial system of the Russian Empire was established in the mid-19th century, whCaesar Alexander II undertook a comprehensive reform of the judiciary in his country. This system was based in part on both the English judicial system and the French judicial system, and was based on some basic principles: the separation of the judiciary from the administrative branch; the independence of judges and courts; the publicity of trials and the oral nature of proceedings; and the equality of all members of different social classes before the law. Furthermore, democracy had beintroduced through the adoption of the jury system and the election of judges. The establishment of a judicial system based on these principles has bea radical shift in view of the Russian State, since it is no longer considered to be tyrannical, having limited the adjudication of disputes to courts that are not subject to executive authority. This has made the judicial system immune to bureaucracy in its bad sense, but during the last years of Alexander II and during Alexander III, several attempts have bemade to gradually re-establish and restore the competencies granted to the judiciary to Caesar. In 1944, the Allies liberated France in the so-called Normandy landing, while the Soviet Union recovered all the areas it had lost and invaded Germany and its allies. In 1944 and 1945, Japan regressed in south central China and in the Burma campaign, while the Allies paralyzed the Japanese Imperial Navy and took control of the main islands in the Pacific. The war in Europe ended with the invasion of Germany by the Allies, the control of Berlin by the Soviet Union and the unconditional surrender of Germany on May 8, 1945. The Potsdam conference was thheld near Berlin, during which the Potsdam Declaration was issued on 26 June 1945, and on 6 August and 9 August 1945 the United States dropped two nuclear bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki (in turn), followed by the surrender of Japan on 15 August 1945. The Second World War changed the world ' s political and military map and social structure, and led to the creation of the United Nations to strengthinternational cooperation and prevent future conflicts. The winning Powers of the war, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, the United Kingdom and France, became permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. The United States and the Soviet Union have emerged as superpowers on the international scene and the influence of European Powers has diminished. This paved the way for the cold war, which has continued in the next 46 years. Countries where industry has beaffected have gone to reform their economic situation, but at the political level, specifically in Europe, an integration phase has begun in an effort to avoid war-caused hostilities, and Europeans have a common identity. In general, the beginning date of the war is September 1, 1939, whthe German invasion of Poland began, followed by the declaration of war by Britain and France against Germany on September 3, and in the Pacific, the beginning date of the war is the beginning of the Second Japanese-Chinese War on July 7, 1937, so that some consider the beginning date to be the Japanese invasion of Manchuria on September 19, 1931.

Public health services are universal and available to all citizens of the State free of charge. In any case, taxes finance the construction and maintenance of health centres and hospitals, with the State spending about 9% of its GDP on the health sector. Statistics for 2012 indicate that there are 1.85 doctors and 2.3 beds in Brazilian hospitals per 1,000 inhabitants. Public health problems persist in Brazil despite the progress made since the establishment of the comprehensive health-care system in 1988, with the main problems to be solved in 2006 being high infant mortality rates (2.51 per cent) and maternal mortality rates (73.1 per 1,000 births). The Brazilian health sector is affected by other figures, such as the number of deaths from non-communicable diseases, such as cardiovascular diseases (151.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants) and cancer (72.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants). Preventable external factors such as car accidents, violence and suicide caused 14.9% of the country ' s total deaths. The Brazilian health system was ranked 125th out of 191 countries valued by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2000. The Federal Constitution and the National Education Controls Act and its foundations provide for the duty of the Federative Government of Brazil, its states, federal provinces and municipalities to administer and regulate their own education systems. These public education systems are responsible for supporting themselves, by managing their own funding and associated mechanisms and securing sources of funding. The Constitution allocates 25% of the State budget and 18% of federal and local taxes to the education sector. The literacy rate was 93.4% of Brazilians, according to figures from the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) in 2019, meaning that 11.3% of the population (6.6%) are still illiterate, with the literacy rate reaching about 97% in some states such as Rio de Janeiro and Santa Catarina, with functional illiteracy equivalent to 21.6% of the population.

During this period, the Church faced colonial violations by the Portuguese and Spanish Governments. In South America, the Jesuits protected indigenous peoples from slavery by establishing semi-autonomous settlements called Jesuit settlements. Pope Gregori XVI challenged Spanish and Portuguese sovereignty, appointed his candidates bishops in the colonies, condemned slavery and the slave trade in 1839 (the Pontifical Decree of the Supreme Divorcer), and agreed to the installation of indigenous clergy despite governmental racism. Indian Christians believe that Thomas is the founder of the Christian faith in Kerala. They're called Saint Tomma's Christians. Society was very small until Jesuit Francis Xavier (1502-1552) began missionary work. He was followed by Roberto de Nobelli (1577. 1656), a Jesuit missionary from Tuscan who went to proselytize in southern India. He was a pioneer of seduction, adopting many of the practices of the Brahmin, which, in his view, were not contrary to Christianity. He lived like the Brahmin, learned Sanskrit, and gave Christianity as part of Indian beliefs, not as a match to Portuguese colonial culture. He allowed the use of all customs, which, in his view, did not directly conflict with Christian teachings. By 1640, there were 40,000 Christians in Madurai alone. In 1632, Pope Gregory gave permission for this approach. But strong anti-Jewish sentiments in Portugal, France and evin Rome have reversed the results. This ended successful Catholic missions in India. On September 12, 1744, Pope Benedict XIV banned the so-called Milibar rituals in India, transforming leading Indian communities that wanted to adhere to their traditional cultures from the Catholic Church. The hostility of the clergy in the French Revolution witnessed the comprehensive nationalization of church property and attempts to establish a State-run church. A large number of priests refused to take the constitutional oath before the National Assembly, which led to the prohibition of the Church and its replacement by a new religion of worship of the mind, but it was never popular.

After the early 2003 election, in which the right-wing list of Pem Fortein lost most of its seats, a new tripartite government was formed with the participation of the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Democrats ' Party 66. The Government has introduced an ambitious programme aimed at reforming welfare State systems, public health care and migration policy. The Government did not last long as it soon fell in June 2006, whits smaller partner, the Democrats ' Party 66, put forward a motion to deny confidence to the Minister of Immigration and Community Integration Rita Verdonek, who belonged to the People ' s Party for Freedom and Liberal Democracy, the second partner of the coalition. Verdonek had instructed an inquiry into doubts about the validity of asylum procedures under which the Somali MP, Ian Harsi Ali, had acquired Dutch citizenship belonging to the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy (PPL), raising questions about the political integrity and credibility of Deputy Ian Harsi and about the extent and depth of the differences among liberals. The tripartite coalition collapsed and a business government was formed that included the People ' s Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Christian Democratic Appeal until the 22 November 2006 general elections. In those elections, the Christian Democratic Appeal Party maintained its status as the largest party in the country, while the Socialist Party made the greatest gains. The formation of the new Government took three months of negotiations and ended with a coalition from the middle left that included the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, the Christian Union and the Dutch Labour Party. But the government of the Central Left Coalition did not complete its mandate. The coalition was again over-contracted and the government collapsed on 20 February 2010, whthe Dutch Labour Party refused to renew the Dutch army's stay in Uruzkan State in Afghanistan. Early elections were held on 9 June 2010, with devastating results for the Christian Democratic Appeal Party, which lost nearly half of its seats in the House of Representatives to 21.

Stars with a greater mass of the sun explode in the form of a greater irritant or collapse under gravity, forming a black hole. Some scientists tend to divide the base mode belt into three sections, whthey want to define the different nuclear interactions taking place in the star, and those divisions are: the top, the middle and the bottom, a classification based on the mass of the star: large, medium or small. This division also gives energy transmission to the star. If the star has a mass less than the mass of the Sun (<0.5 M▸), the energy transmission of the star through the thermal load is entirely, and if the star has a medium mass (0.5 _____ 1.5M) the energy transmission in the heart of the star through radiation is accompanied by the thermal pregnancy in the top of the heart to the surface. If the mass of the star is greater than 5 and 1 of the mass of the Sun, the energy transfer at the heart of the star is by pregnancy and is supported by a layer where the energy is transmitted by radiation. Large stars can also be more precisely divided by their mass: high mass and medium mass, so that the boundary betwethem is at 8MY (i.e. eight times the solar mass). According to that classification, a star with a mass greater than 8 times the mass of the Sun evolves into a larger concussion, and that star with a lower mass ends in a form or a neutron star or a white dwarf. The sun is located on the curve of the graph of the basic pattern approximately in the center (specifically in the lower third on the right) where it is considered to be among the stars with a small mass. Its mass is usually takas the average mass of stars, but recent research shows that its mass is somewhat more than average, and that the average mass of all stars is about 6 and 0 of the mass of the Sun.

The wave (also called wave collection) in physics is a form of energy transmission, which moves in a physical medium (except for electromagnetic waves and some forms of quantum molecules with wave characteristics), where waves move and energy moves from one place to another without permanently dislodging the middle molecules, i.e. no mass is transported with the wave moving, but the middle molecules move in a deliberate way or parallel to the direction of the wave movement around a fixed position. The electromagnetic waves spread into the vacuum, i.e. without the need for a physical medium. Light, radio waves, X-rays and gamma rays are examples of electromagnetic waves. One characteristic of the electromagnetic wave is that it spreads into the vacuum at the speed of light, the speed of which is estimated at 299,792,458 metres per second. Waves are usually a frequency of some type of intensity in successive intervals at a intervals betwethem, and the number of waves passed in a segment divided by the unit of time is called frequency. The horizontal distance of one wave is called wavelength. The waves are spread in multiple types of physical media, which require some coherence to ensure transmission of wave signals, and the waves can be classified according to their physical properties: waves are characterized by a combination of physical behaviors: waves can be divided into length waves and accidental waves. Spinal waves (reviewed) in a flexible medium (e.g. solid body and free surface of liquid) whose molecules have sufficient coherency forces to enable the vibrating molecule to move its adjacent molecules vertically in the direction of wave proliferation. There are two types of wave: f=1-T{displaystyle f=1-T} where T is the time of each period (cycle). d is the frequency of the wave and its standard Hz unit, or 1/second. N is the time betwethe beginning and the end of one wave, or the time betwetwo successive peaks.

The Red Sea is higher than the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, and the Canal is therefore the tidal strait that pours the waters of the Red Sea into the Mediterranean Sea. For bitter lakes, which are highly salted natural lakes forming part of the Canal, the migration of red sea organisms to the Mediterranean has beprevented for decades, but after the gradual equivalence of lake salinity with the Red Sea, the barrier that prevented the migration of these organisms has beremoved, and plants and animals that migrate from the Red Sea have begun to colonize the Eastern Mediterranean. The Red Sea is generally considered to be more salty and less food resources than the Atlantic Ocean, and therefore the Eastern Mediterranean is considered to have less food resources for red sea organisms than Atlantic organisms. Accordingly, it is the Red Sea that invaded local Mediterranean organisms, not the other way around; this phenomenon is known as the migration of marine organisms. The construction of the high dam in Aswan, which cuts off the Nile River in the 1960s, has reduced the flow of fresh water and nutrients rich from the Nile to the Eastern Mediterranean, thus exacerbating the conditions for the impact of invasive organisms. Invasive organisms have become a major component of the Mediterranean ecosystem and have serious impacts on the sea environment, threatening many local and endemic species. In the first look at some groups of aliorganisms, it appears that over 70% of the native non-indigenous deciles of legs and about 63% of the Mediterranean exotic fish originating from the Indian Pacific Ocean are considered to be aliorganisms on the Mediterranean Sea via the Suez Canal. This makes the channel the first route to reach the Mediterranean invasive organisms. The impact of some migratory marine organisms has befound to be significant, particularly in the Mediterranean Shami basin, where local organisms have bereplaced and converted into familiar.

Earth Day, an annual event celebrated around the world on April 22 to show support for environmental protection. Earth Day was first celebrated in 1970, and now includes events organized worldwide by the Earth Day Network in more than 193 countries around the world. The historic Paris Convention was signed by the United States, China and some 120 other countries on Earth Day in 2016. The signing of the Convention included a key requirement for the entry into force of the historic draft of the Climate Protection Treaty, adopted unanimously by 195 States present at the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris. Peace activist John McConnell, at the 1969 UNESCO Conference in San Francisco, proposed a day to honour the Earth and the concept of peace, which was first celebrated on March 21, 1970, the first spring day in the northern hemisphere. The Nature Balance Day was later endorsed in a declaration writtby McConnell and signed by Secretary-General U Thant at the United Nations. A month later, American Senator Gaylord Nelson founded a separate Earth Day as the first environmental awareness day on April 22, 1970, and Nelson later received the Presidential Order of Freedom in recognition of his work. WhLand Day was set on April 22, in the United States, an organization launched by Dennis Hayes, the main national coordinator in 1970, made Earth Day a world day in 1990, and evorganized the event in 141 countries. Many societies are celebrating Earth Week, an entire week of activities focusing on the environmental issues facing the world. The Science March took place on Earth Day in 2017 (22 April 2017) and was followed by the People ' s Climate Alert (29 April 2017).

The mass of great black holes is betwemillions of solar blocks to billions of solar blocks, and in most cases appears to be found in galaxies' centers, and how those black holes and their relationship to the formation of a galaxy around them are still under the research of astronomers. A powerful radio source in the center of our galaxy is the Milky Way galaxy, which has a heavy radio radiator called A* (or a short Sgr A* or in Arabic: an arami a*) mass of about 4.3 million solar blocks, and its mass was estimated years ago on the basis of near-gas clouds (such as a so-called small spiral arm) which resulted in a mass of 2.7 million solar blocks, but the use of higher variation and more sensitive telescopes has enabled scientists to deduce its mass at the center of the galaxy by watching nearby star orbits and their proximity to orbits around it, such as S0-102 and S2 star, and recent observations have shown that its mass is much larger; it is 4.3 million solar blocks. The sightings indicate that black holes may have formed with galaxies at the same time and that they have helped to form a galaxy around them, and this is an important subject that scientists are interested in explaining. In the middle of the Milky Way galaxy, the target radio source A* (Sgr*A) is a massive black hole of 4.3 million solar blocks. A few years ago, mass estimation depends on gas withdrawal control (e.g., called mini-spiral), still at about 2.7 million solar blocks. Thanks to improved accuracy and sensitivity of telescopes, the mass of the black hole in the center of the galaxy can be more accurately determined by a path analysis, e.g. the stars S0-102 or S2 that orbit the black hole.

Thermocouple is an electrical component used to measure temperatures. This type of measurement is of great importance in measuring high-value temperatures. One of its advantages is low manufacturing cost, strong design and user-friendly especially whused in complex and variable standard systems. The double consists of two different metal that are connected to each other at the tip of the double. Whthere is a thermal variation at the tip of the double which in turn contains the sides of the different metals, there is an electrical tension proportional to the temperature passing through each of the metals. The more heat the metal, the more power it generates. So each side passes to a metal, different heat from the other metal corridor, and two different electric currents reach the other end. At this end, which binds the metal together, an electrical effort is generated because there is a variation in currents. An electronic component measures this generated effort, converts its value as needed to the thermal value shown on display, or passes the value to another component for use in another standard machine or the like. The scientific background of the modus operandi depends on the Sibek coefficient discovered by the German scientist Thomas Sebeck. Whthe heat of a metal changes, its electrons move faster. Whthe velocity of electrons in the two related metals varies in the thermocouple, the electrons overlap with each other where the metal meets. And that's where there's a surplus of electrons on one side, and a shortage of electrons on the other. This difference generates an electrical current that relates to the metal type on the one hand, and heat on the other. This current is called the electro-thermal current. These two currents are connected to an electronic board, where the current difference is measured by a microvolt based on a thermal difference of one calvin. The value of the electro-thermal current in microvolt per 1 Kelvin is a heat differential.

In the 13th century, the Sultanate of Egypt extended its control over the Levant until it was defeated by the Ottoman State in 1517. During the nineteenth century, the national awakening among Jews led to the establishment of the Zionist movement in the diaspora, followed by waves of migration to Ottoman Syria and later mandated Palestine. In 1947, the United Nations adopted a plan for the partition of Palestine recommending the establishment of independent Arab and Jewish States and international Jerusalem. The plan was accepted by the Jewish Agency, while rejected by Arab leaders. The following year, the Jewish Agency declared the independence of the State of Israel, and the subsequent Arab-Israeli war of 1948 saw Israel on most of the former lands of assignment, while the West Bank and Gaza Strip were under the control of neighbouring Arab States. Since then, Israel has fought several wars with Arab States. Since the Six Day War of 1967, Israel has occupied both the West Bank and the Golan Heights and the Gaza Strip (still considered occupied after the disengagement in 2005, although some legal experts oppose this claim). Its laws had beextended to include the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank. Israel ' s occupation of Palestinian territories is the longest military occupation in the world in modern times. Efforts to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have not resulted in a final peace agreement. However, peace treaties have besigned betweIsrael, Egypt and Jordan. In its basic laws, Israel defines itself as a Jewish, democratic and nation State of the Jewish people. The country enjoys a liberal democracy (one of only two countries in the Middle East and North Africa region, and the other is Tunisia), with a parliamentary system, proportional representation and universal suffrage. The Prime Minister is the Head of Government and the Knesset is the Legislative Council. As of 2019, Israel is a developed country and a member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), with 31 or 32 largest economies in the world by gross domestic product (GDP).

Abortion is a language of an abortion that stopped growing before completion, or an abortion is an incomplete organ; in the language of dropping the fetus; the mother's delivery to her child before completion; it is an abortion. It is also called ablution in the sense that it causes abortion. It is the termination of the pregnancy by leaving or removing the fetus from the womb before he becomes able to live. Abortion can occur automatically because of complications during pregnancy and is called spontaneous abortion. Abortion induced to maintain a pregnant woman ' s health status is known as therapeutic abortion, while induced abortion for any other reason is known as voluntary abortion. The term abortion oftrefers to induced abortion. Inducing abortion is one of the safest medical procedures in the developed countries where the law allows it to be performed. The Oxford Lexicon defines this operation as the deliberate termination of a human pregnancy, oftcarried out during the 28th week of pregnancy. Abortion has a long history and has beperformed, inter alia, through herbs, the use of sharp instruments, physical trauma and other traditional methods. Contemporary medicine uses drugs and surgical procedures to induce abortion. Sharia, custom and culture have different views on abortion from country to country. There is debate in many countries about the ethical and legal extent of abortion. Abortion and related issues play a prominent role in national political life in many States and oftinvolve opposition on the part of movements opposed to abortion, and support on the part of supporters of wom' s right to choose around the world. Abortions have declined worldwide, in conjunction with increased family planning, education and contraceptive services. The number of abortions in the United States of America decreased by 8% from 1996 to 2003. Automatic abortion is the release of the foetus from the womb due to accidental trauma or natural causes and usually occurs before the twenty-second week of pregnancy; the definition of the age of pregnancy varies from country to country.

Jerusalem is characterized by the Mediterranean climate (Csa Cobin classification), with a dry hot summer, and a mildly cold winter. Snow usually falls once or twice during winter, although the city experiences a high snowfall once every three to four years, on average, with a short-lived accumulation. January is the coldest month of the year, with an average temperature of 9.1°C (48.4°C); July and August are the hottest, with an average temperature of 24.2°C (75.6°C), and summer months are usually dry. The average annual rainfall is about 537 mm (21 inches) betweOctober and May, while the other months are mostly out of rainfall. Snowfall is not common, but heavy snowfall is rare. Jerusalem received more than 30 cm (12 inches) of snow on December 13, 2013, which almost crippled the city. With average summer temperatures similar to the coasts, the Mediterranean sea influence is strong, especially givthat Jerusalem is on a latitude similar to the warm deserts not far to the east. The highest temperature recorded in Jerusalem was 44.4 °C (111.9°C) on 28 and 30 August 1881, and the lowest temperature recorded on 25 January 1907 was -6.7 °C (19.9°C). Most air pollution in Jerusalem comes from car traffic. Many major streets in Jerusalem have not bebuilt to accommodate this large volume of traffic, resulting in traffic congestion and more carbon monoxide emissions in the air.

Before the arrival of the Inca, a variety of different families of indigenous Americans who settled in Ecuador emerged. They have different languages, and nationalities have emerged in different places. Some sailed to Ecuador on a raft from Central America, others came to Ecuador via the Amazon rafts, others came from North South America, and others went up from the southern part of South America through the Andes or by sailing on boats. These groups eventually came with similar cultures, although their languages were irrelevant, and evthough they lived in the same environment. People from the coast have befishing, people from the high Andes have befarming, and people from the Amazon basin have befishing on the old nomadic roads. Whthe Inca arrived, they found that these continents were designed so that the Inca took two generations of rulers - Toba the Inca Yubanki and Huaina Kapak - to accommodate these continents in the Inca Empire. The inhabitants of the indigenous continents, which were the cause of most of the problems, were deported to remote areas of Peru, Bolivia and northern Argentina. Similarly, a number of sincere Inca subjects from Peru and Bolivia were brought to Ecuador to prevent the insurgency. Thus, the Ecuadorian Highlands became part of the Inca Empire in 1463, which shared the same language. In contrast, whInca continued to invade coastal and eastern Ecuador and the Amazon jungles in Ecuador, they found both the environment and the indigenous population more hostile. Moreover, whthe Incas tried to subdue them, the indigenous peoples withdrew into the interior and resorted to guerrilla tactics. As a result, inca expansion in the Amazon basin and the Pacific coast of Ecuador was hampered. Indigenous peoples in the Amazon forests and coastal areas of Ecuador remained relatively independent, evSpanish soldiers and missionaries who had difficult access to them.

There is no night in space, no clouds, no atmosphere to block sunlight, and the solar energy is available by watt per square metre (m2) for any distance d from the sun that can be calculated in E = 1366/d2; d is used as an astronomical unit of measure. To convert solar energy into a pioneer electricity will require large structures. The rate of consumption of advanced countries is 2 kW per person (or 10 mW per person per hour per year). The needs in space will undoubtedly be significant, as two solar cells of the International Space Station of eight cells are capable of covering the needs of 30 medium-Earth dwellings. Betwe1978 and 1981, the United States Congress allowed NASA and the United States Department of Energy to study the idea. They organize a programme for the evaluation and development of energy-producing satellites, which has remained the most complete and unverified study on this subject. Especially in the absence of gravity, solar light can be used directly with solar furnaces made of very light metal panels capable of generating temperature in thousands of degrees or reflecting sunlight on civilizations, at very simple cost. Energy may also be an export product of space colonies using the transmission of radio energy by electromagnetic radiation from orbital solar stations towards the moon or the Earth. The moon nights are equivalent to two weeks, while the areas in the moon poles are permanently vulnerable to the sun. Mars is more remote than the sun and is sometimes exposed to sandstorms that slightly reduce its rays. With less solar radiation leaking than on Earth, there is hope that solar energy will be invested equally effectively and, moreover, more regularly for sunlight. So nuclear power may remain an option for continued energy on these celestial bodies, but no raw uranium metal has yet bediscovered, so raw material from the Earth such as that planned for Mars by NASA may have to be brought in.

Dr. Said Chepan (2 April 1925 - 4 December 2022) is an Algerian professor in Laayoune, former Minister of Religious Affairs and Waqfs of the First Government of Ould Hamroush (9 September 1989 to 25 July 1990), the Second Government of Hamroush (25 July 1990 to 4 June 1991) and former President of the Algerian Muslim Society of Scientists, and the brother of Sheikh Abdulrahman Cheban. Born on 2 April 1925 in the village of Al-Sharfah (now Boirah State), he studied at the old mosque in the village, thenrolled in the primary school of the people with a scalpel, where she was ththe only school in the region, with a primary degree in May 1937, followed by a high school in BAknon, currently in the vicinity of the Second World War in 1939. The high school was transferred for a year to the teacher training school in Bouzaria. He dropped out of school from 1942 to 1943 because of the bombing of the Bejo High School (now Prince Abdul Qader) by German aircraft. After the English and American entered Algeria, he returned to his town to the Old Mosque to learn Arabic well and was studied by Sheikh Erzaki bin Shablah. In July 1946, he received a certificate of baccalaureate and joined the Algerian Islamic Scout and the secret activity of the Algerian People ' s Party. He thtravelled to Germany and joined the University of Strasbourg. In March 1956, he participated in the Congress of the Algerian Students ' Union in Paris and met Mohamed Sadiq BYahi and Radha Malik. He participated in the Strasbourg conference with Ahmed Taleb Brahimi, Belaid Abdussalam, Mohamed Sadiq BYahya and others. He participated in the student strike in May 1956. Thin July 1958, he presented his thesis, which was ready two years ago. In 1959, he passed the ophthalmology exam. In May 1962, he supervised the Tizi and Zou Hospital at the request of the National Liberation Front (NLF) and remained in it for six years.

The Catalan Club logo went through several stages of evolution and change. The first logo of the club was a crown, above and above a bat, with a number of yellow, red and white lines, used from 1899 to 1910, the bat symbolized freedom. The bat symbolized greatness and had no political connotations at the time. The bat was colored in Catalonia (yellow and red) as a symbol of the identity of the Catalan Club. In 1910, the theme of the club changed and became typical today: on the left side up there is a red cross (+) surrounded by white, the symbol of St. Jargus, and on the right side up there are yellow and red lines and they symbolize Catalonia, the territory of the club and Barcelona, and at the bottom of the logo are blue and red lines and those lines symbolize the club. The former club player Carlis Komamala is an innovator of the club's logo after the club organized a design competition in 1910 to be a logo for the club and the design of that player was selected. The club logo has undergone a number of minor changes during its history, either for political reasons or for reasons related to the introduction of certain aesthetics to the club logo. Del Parsa () was the official anthem of the club, which began in 1974 at Camp Nu on the occasion of the club's seventy-fiveth anniversary of the club, by Jamie Peckas and Joseph Maria Espinosa, and by Manuel Falls Gorina.

These stars are said to be in the main sequence and are called dwarf stars. Starting at 0 hrs in the main sequence, helium at the core of the star is increasing steadily, the rate of nuclear integration at the core of the star will slowly increase, as will the temperature and brightness of the star. The Sun, for example, is estimated to have increased its brightness by about 40% since it reached the main sequence stage 4.6 billion (4.6 x 109) years ago. Each star generates star winds from primary particles (mostly protons and neutrinos) that flow continuously into space, for most stars the amount of mass lost with those winds is modest. The Sun loses 14 - 10 percent of its solar mass each year because of the mass becoming energy during nuclear fusion and because of particles released from it into space, or about 0.01% of its total mass per year. Nevertheless, a number of very large stars may lose 10 - 7 to 10 - 4-5 from its solar mass each year, affecting its significant development. Stars starting with more than 50 solar blocks may lose more than half of their mass while remaining in their main sequence. The length of the star in the main sequence depends primarily on the amount of fuel that integrates and the rate of hydrogintegration, i.e., its primary mass and glow. For the sun, its life is estimated to be about 10 billion (1010) years. Large stars consume their fuel very quickly and short-term, with very high temperature, reaching billions of degrees. Low-mass stars consume their fuel very slowly and react at lower temperatures (about 12 million degrees Celsius). The stars of less than 0.25 solar mass are called: red dwarfs are able to integrate hydroginto nearly its mass as fuel, while stars with a mass of 1 solar mass can consume only about 10% of their mass as fuel.

During the dark ages, Christian culture was not familiar with most of the knowledge acquired by the Greeks, but this knowledge flourished in the Muslim world. As a result, the thought associated with studying the universe in Europe was limited during the Middle Ages. The next great development on the road to modern scientific thinking in the study of the universe was the emergence of Isaac Newton (1642-1727) on the scene. Newton was able to show in his book the Principles (1687) that Kepler's elliptical movement was a natural consequence of the existence of a general universal law of gravity. The modern era of cosmology began in the early years of the 20th century, whthere was a complete reformulation of the laws of nature. Albert Einstein (1879-1955) put forward the principle of proportionality, thus undermining the Newton concept of space and time. Subsequently, Newton ' s General Attraction Act was replaced by general relativity. However, although these conceptual developments have paved the way, the final steps towards the modern era of cosmology have not beundertakby theoretical physicists, but by observational astronomers. The Trabzon Empire was a royal empire, one of the three successors to the Byzantine Empire that flourished from the 13th to the 15th centuries, which included the lands of the far north-west corner of Anatolia (Pantus) and the southern Crimea peninsula. The empire was formed in 1204 after the Georgian campaign in Chaldia and Pavlonia, led by Alexios Komninos, a few weeks before Constantinople was looted. ThAlexios declared himself Emperor of Trabzon (now Tarabzon, Turkey). Alexios and David Komninos, grandchildrof the deposed Emperor Andronicos I Comenos, have exerted pressure on the Byzantine Emperor Alexius V Ducas, claiming to be Roman emperors. Byzantine emperors who, as reported by the Byzantine authors, such as George Bagimir, Nikiforos Gregorias, John Lazaropoulos and Basileus Pisarion, were considered to be the princes of the Laser people, whereas their ownership was also known as Lasika. In other words, their country was known as the Principality of Lizes, and so, from the point of view of the Byzantine writers connected to the Lascaris and later to the Bailiwicks, the rulers of Trabzon were not emperors. After the Crusaders took down the fourth Crusade of Alexios V and founded the Latin Empire, the Trabzon Empire became one of three Byzantine States to succeed the Imperial Throne, along with a Neat Empire under the Lascaris family, and the Eberus Dispotic under a branch of the Angelos family. Subsequent wars caused the emergence of the Thessaloniki Empire, the colonial government that emerged from Iberus, the collapse in the aftermath of conflicts with Nicaea and Bulgaria, and the restoration of the final Necate empire of Constantinople in 1261. Despite the restoration of a pure empire of Constantinople, the emperors of Trabzon continued to label themselves as Roman emperors for two decades, and continued to press their claim to the Imperial Throne. The Emperor of Trabzon John II officially abandoned the demands of the Roman and Constantinople Empire itself after 21 years of the control of the city by a Nigerian empire, which changed his title from the Emperor and the tyrant of the Romans to the Emperor and the tyrant of the entire East, Iberia and Beretta.

According to the 2011 German census, Christianity is the largest religion in Germany, with 66.8% of the total population. In relation to the total population, 31.7% declared themselves Protestant, including members of the Evangelical Church in Germany (30.8%) and the Free Churches (German: Evangelische Freikirch(0.9%), and 31.2% declared themselves Catholic. Orthodox Christians made up 1.3%, and other religions accounted for 2.7%. According to the latest data from 2016, the Catholic Church and the Evangelical Church respectively claimed ownership of 28.5% and 27.5% of the population. Both large churches have lost a large number of followers in recent years. In 2011, 33% of Germans did not belong to any of the officially recognized religious communities with special status. Latinism in Germany was stronger in the former East Germany, which used to be predominantly Protestant before the state was united, as well as in major urban areas. Islam is the second largest religion in the country. In the 2011 census, 1.9% of the population (1.52 million people) declared their religion Islam, but this figure is unreliable because a significant number of followers (and other religions, such as Judaism) used their right not to answer the question. Figures from Religionswissenschaftlicher Medi- und Informationsdienst indicate that there were 4.4 million Muslims (about 5.5 per cent of the population) in 2015. A study by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees found that betwe2011 and 2015 the number of Muslims increased by 1.2 million, mostly because of migration. Most Muslims are Sunnis and highs from Turkey, but there are few Shia, Ahmadiyah and other communities. According to the Pew Centre in 2016, there were about 5 million Muslims in Germany, representing about 6.1% of the total population.

The Litseng diamond mine is located in the Kingdom of Lesotho, a South African State that is closed and not at sea, owned by Jim Diamond and the Government of Lesotho. It is the largest diamond mine in the world, where it descends below ground to a depth of ~3,100 metres (10,000 feet). It has a very low ore (less than 2 carats/100 tons) but is well known for producing large pieces of diamonds, with the highest proportion of large diamonds (above 10 carats), giving it a dollar value per carat higher than any other diamond mine. The global average is about $81 per carat, while the average for the first six months of 2007 was over $1894 per carat. Because of the extreme depth of the mine, the mine ' s temperature drops to sub-20 degrees Celsius, and snow falls in winter routinely, but it is unusual for hot Africa. Lesotho Promise: Lesotho Promise announced its discovery on 4 October 2006 and weighs 603 carats (121 grams) of white diamonds, the largest diamond discovered in this century and ranked 15 in terms of the largest volume of discovered diamonds, the rarest stone color and class (D) of diamonds. Lesotho, Lesotho Brown, extracted from the land in 1967, was previously the largest discovered jewel in the Litsang mine and weighed 601 carats (120 grams). It was announced by Jim Diamond, a 493-carat-weight company, and ranked 18 as the largest diamond found. Graff-SAFDICO partnership was sold to Graff-Savedico and their partners for $10 million. It was extracted in 2004, and it weighs 123 carats. On 21 September 2008, Jim Diamond announced that it had found a 478 carat diamond of high quality, qualifying it to be 20 in terms of the size of the diamonds discovered.

The 1960 calendar began on January 1, 1960 and ended on December 31, 1969. The term refers to the cross-cutting cultural and political trends around the world in that era known as the 1960s. This definition of cultural contract is broader than actual contracts, as it began with Kennedy's assassination around 1963 and ended with Watergate's scandal around 1974. ∙ During the 1960s, Africa ' s transition from colonialism to independence accelerated considerably, as is known for the decision to decolonize Africa. Thirty-two States gained their independence from 1960 to 1968, representing the end of the European empires that dominated the African continent. However, the noble aspirations of these new nations quickly faded, and many nations descended into chaos, democracy, dictatorship and/or civil war, and the road to prosperity was difficult in most parts of the brown continent: by 2011, by many measures, Africa still had the largest poverty rate in the world and the lowest life expectancy. The United States-Soviet space race dominated the 1960s. The Soviets sent the first man, Yuri Gagarin, to outer space during the Vostok 1 mission on April 12, 1961 and recorded a series of other successes, but by mid-decade the United States was taking the lead. In May 1961, President Kennedy set the target of landing a man on the Moon by the end of the 1960s. In June 1963, Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space during the Vostok Mission 6. In 1965, the Soviet launched the first probe to hit another planet of the solar system (Venera 3), and the first probe to make the landing easy on the moon, Luna 9.

A spacecraft is a vehicle that is usually manned by one or more astronauts capable of reaching outer space, loaded on a powerful rocket to take off. The space shuttle is a three-part vehicle: the shuttle starts to take off vertically like a conventional rocket, the two solid-fueled rockets are separated after the fuel has run out, and the shuttle continues to climb with the help of the outer fuel tank, until the spacecraft alone arrives in outer space and the empty tank separates and falls into the ocean. This is after its spinning cycle around the Earth to gain the speed of escape from the Earth ' s gravity, estimated at 11.93 km/s. After the shuttle completes its mission, it will return to Earth and land in accordance with a track landing process in which it will follow the landing, up and down in order to reduce the temperature of the heat infestation and speed. In European countries that have begreatly affected by Protestant reform, Protestantism remains the most practised religion. These include the countries of the North and the United Kingdom. In other Protestant historical strongholds such as Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Latvia, Estonia and Hungary, it remains one of the most popular religions. Although the Czech Republic had one of the most important pre-reform movements, there were few Protestant followers; this was mainly due to historical reasons such as the persecution of Protestants by the Habsburg Catholics, restrictions during communist rule, as well as persistent secularism. Over the past few decades, religious practice has declined with increasing secularism. According to a 2012 study on debt in the European Union conducted by Europarometer, Protestants made up about 12% of the European Union population. According to the Pew Research Centre, Protestants accounted for approximately five (or 18 per cent) of the continent ' s total Christian population in 2010. Clark and Pierre estimate that Protestants made up 15% of all Europeans in 2009, while Noel claims that less than 12% lived in Europe in 2010. Changes in Protestantism throughout the world during the last century have besignificant. Since 1900, Protestantism has spread rapidly in Africa, Asia, Oceania and Latin America. This caused Protestants to be called a largely non-Western religion. Much of the growth in Protestant numbers took place after the Second World War, whcolonialism in Africa was brought to an end and different restrictions against Protestants were removed in Latin American countries. According to one source, Protestants made up 2.5%, about 2%, and about 0.5% of the total population of Latin America, Africa and Asia. In 2000, the proportion of Protestants on the continents mentioned was 17%, more than 27% and about 6% respectively.

After the end of World War I, Palestine was under British mandate until 1948. On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly approved the decision to divide Palestine into two Jewish and Arab States (Palestine) and to internationalize the Jerusalem area (i.e., to make it an international zone that does not belong to a particular State and to place it under international rule). Philippines () is a constitutional republic in the western Pacific region of South-East Asia. It is an archipelago of 7,641 islands, bordered by Taiwan to the north by the Luzon Strait, and Vietnam to the west by the South China Sea. The Solo Sea in the south-west separates it from Borneo Island and Slips Sea to the south separates it from other islands in Indonesia. It is bounded from the east by the Philippine Sea. It is divided into three main geographical sections, namely, Luzon, Pisaia and Mindanao. Manila is the capital, while the most densely populated city is Quezon and both cities are part of what is called Metro Manila. The population of the Philippines is estimated to be 92 million, placing it in the 12th place globally according to the population census. It is estimated that there are 11 million Filipino expatriates worldwide. There are multiple races and cultures throughout the islands. Its tropical climate is one of the richest biodiversity regions in the world. The Nagreto ethnic of prehistoric times was one of the first inhabitants of the archipelago. They were followed by successive waves of Australian peoples with whom they brought influences from Malawian, Hindu and Islamic cultures. China ' s influence has also entered the country through trade. The arrival of Ferdinand Magellan in 1521 marked the beginning of an era of Spanish interests, which eventually led to the country ' s occupation. The Philippines became the Asian Centre for the Treasure Fleet of Acapulco, Manila. Christianity has spread widely in the country. As the twentieth century entered, events followed quickly and in a short period of time from the Philippine Revolution to the Spanish-American War, the Philippine-American War. Subsequently, the United States replaced Spain as a dominant force. Apart from the period of Japanese occupation, the United States retained sovereignty over the islands until the end of the Second World War whthe Philippines gained independence.

In astronomy, the dual planet is a dual system consisting of two objects with a planetary mass. However, this proposal was neglected in favour of the current definition of the planet. In the promotional declaration of mission Smart-1 and before the definition of the International Astronomical Union of the Planet (IAU), ESA once indicated that the Moon's Earth system constituted a dual planet. Informal reference is made to some binary asteroids that are almost equal in mass at times as tiny double planets. As an example of the binary asteroid system 69230 Hermes, 90 Antibes, and the binary albums in the Kepler asteroid belt 79360 Sila-Nunam and 1998 WW31. There are discussions about the criteria to be used to distinguish the "dual planet" system from the "tunnel" system. The considerations are as follows: the definition proposed by the International Astronomical Union calls for the two bodies individually to meet the clear orbital standard to be called a dual planet. One of the important considerations in determining "dual planet" is the ratio betwethe mass of the two bodies. The ratio of 1 betwethe two blocks indicates that the two planets are similar in mass, and objects with a close mass ratio tend to be considered as dual planets. Using this definition, Mars moons, buyers, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune can be easily excluded, because they all have less than 0.0025 mass of their planets orbiting around them. Some dwarf planets also have moons, but their mass is actually smaller than the mass of the dwarf planets themselves. The most noteworthy exception is the Pluto regime. The Sharon to Pluto bloc ratio is about 0.117 (approximately 2/17) and is close enough to one, so many scientists have consistently described Pluto and Sharon as "dwarf planets" (called double planets before the 2006 definition of the planet).

Germany seeks to advance a more unified European policy, defence and security apparatus. The development policy of the Federal Republic of Germany is in itself a separate area from German foreign policy, with the Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development having the task of formulating and shaping this policy, which is being applied on the ground by the implementing organizations. The German Government sees development policy as a shared responsibility of the international community. Germany was the third largest global aid donor in 2009 after the United States and France. In 1999, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder ' s Government developed a new-based definition of German foreign policy through participation in NATO ' s decision-making process with regard to the Kosovo war; Germany sent troops to the front of the fighting in a first step since the end of the Second World War in 1945. The Governments of Germany and the United States have a close political alliance. The 1948 Marshall Plan and strong cultural relations had established a strong bond betwethe two countries, although Schroeder was a opposition to the Iraq war, causing some relative coldness in German-American relations. The two countries were economically interdependent: 8.8% of German exports to the United States and 6.6% of German imports to the United States. Germany ' s population was approximately 80.2 million according to the 2011 census, and as of 31 December 2015 it was approximately 81.9 million, rising to 81.3 million in 2019. Germany ranked first in the European Union in terms of population and second in the entire European continent after Russia, and ranked 19 globally in terms of population. Its total fertility rate is one of the lowest in the world at 1.41 childrper woman (2011), and the German Federal Bureau of Statistics expects the population to decline to betwe65 and 70 million by 2060 (65 million if the annual number of immigrants is 100,000 and 70 million if the number of immigrants is 200,000 annually).

Brazilian law is based on the legal system of civil law, and the concepts of civil law prevail over the practice of common law. Most Brazilian law is codified, although non-compliant laws also represent a large part, and play a complementary role. Court decisions establish guidelines and interpretation; however, in other specific cases they are rarely binding. The work of jurists and academic jurists has a strong influence on the establishment of the law and the handling of legal issues. The legal system is based on the Federal Constitution of 5 October 1988 and the Organic Law of Brazil. All other legislation and court decisions must conform to its rules. As of April 2007, 53 amendments had bemade. The states follow their own constitutions, which must not conflict with the Federal Constitution, while the municipalities and the Federal District have basic laws (leis orgânicas), which are applied in a manner similar to the Constitutions. According to Garrett Nagel in his book Advanced Geography, Tunisian tourism benefits from its Mediterranean site and tradition of low-cost holidays from Western Europe. The development of tourism dates back to 1960 through the joint efforts of the Government and private groups. In 1962, tourism achieved 5000 entrances, 4,000 beds and revenues of $2 million and became the main source of foreign exchange in the country. Tunisia is also an attractive destination for a large number of important festivals. The majority of these festivals are held in summer, such as the International Carthage Festival, which is the most important festival in the Arab world that hosts stars and musical bands from all over the world, as well as the Tobraqa Jazz Festival. Until recently, Tunisia ' s main attraction was on the northeast coast around Tunisia. However, the Seventh National Development Plan of 1989 established several new tourist areas, including the resort at the Quantawi marina. The tourism sector now accounts for 6.5% of Tunisian GDP and provides 340,000 jobs, of which 85,000 are direct jobs or 11.5% of the working population with a high proportion of seasonal employment. France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom are the four traditional tourism markets, although Tunisia has decided a few years ago to opits tourism industry to new markets such as Russia and China. Tourism in Tunisia was hit hard in the wake of the attack by the Pardon Museum and the Susah attack in 2015, but Tunisia was able to regain its position as one of the best destinations in Africa and the Mediterranean shortly thereafter, reaching figures of over 6 per cent in 2010 in 2018, with 8.3 million visitors. The consequences of the Corona virus pandemic in Tunisia for the Tunisian tourism sector were described as catastrophic.

For example, the start-ups of air turbines used to operate giant jet engines are much smaller and lighter than the electric engine, which produces the same amount of energy. The air drive required to operate the engines is generated through an additional aircraft power unit (APU) or external engine if the additional power unit cannot be operated. Once one engine is activated, the air can be used to manage the startup in the other engines. The pressure of a toilet is maintained through the air drivby a pressure regulator. The outer air probe in some aircraft evuses the air-drive to push a filter pump to attract the outer air into a temperature-sensitive chamber. The first jets used the air-drive to drive the gyroscope (for the preservation of balance) in the industrial horizon of the cabin. The eclipse of the Moon is an astronomical phenomenon that occurs whthe shadow of the Earth obscures the sunlight reflected on the Moon in normal conditions. This type is not classified as a legitimate eclipse. So for the total eclipse to happen, the two former eclipses must happen. At the beginning of the total eclipse, the moon's colour tends to be red because of the red rays that cannot be absorbed from the top of the Earth's atmosphere. Whthe sun and the musketeer moon are observed at the same time, this eclipse is called a horizontal eclipse (Selenehelion). This can only occur before sundown or immediately after sunrise, both of which will appear quite above horizon at nearly opposite points in the sky and can be seat the same time as the sun and the musketeer moon, because the breaking of light during the Earth's atmosphere reflects both images above the eastern or western horizon and appear higher in the sky than their true geometric position. The term bloody moon is not a scientific term, but it is used because of the red colour of the fully enclosed moon, due to the penetration of the red sun spectrum (long wavelength) into the Earth's atmosphere. The blue spectrum part (long short wave) is dispersed (see Rilet scattered), as well as the atmospheric pollution factors that affect the amount of radiation whsunlight passes through the Earth's atmosphere. The solar system, the solar system or the solar system is the planetary system that consists of the Sun and all the objects around it, including the Earth and other planets. The solar system includes other smaller crimes, namely, planets dwarfs, asteroids, meteors and comets, as well as a thin cloud of gas and dust known as the middle of the planet. It also orbits the Sun but indirectly, planets called natural satellites or short moons, note 1], numbering more than 150 moons known in the solar system, most of which revolve around gas giants. Two of these satellites are bigger than Mercury. The biggest crime in the solar system, of course, remains the sun, the star that lies at the centre of the system and links it to its gravity, with 99.9% of the mass of the entire system, and the buyer's planet taking the lion's share of what the sun didn't take. It is the sun that shines the light and heat that makes life on Earth possible, yet it's only a medium-sized star. The planets come after the sun, with eight planets in the solar system, in order of distance from the sun: Mercury, flower, earth, Mars (rock planets), buyer, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune (gas giants). The two largest planets, Jupiter and Saturn, consist mainly of hydrogand helium; the other two planets, the most remote from the sun, Uranus and Neptune, are made up of substances with a relatively higher melting point than hydrogand helium. Water, ammonia and methane are examples. All eight planets of the solar system are rotated in a semi-circular path around the Sun, at a level found in a nearly flat disk called the solar system path. The natural or dependent moon, in the most common use, is an astronomical object orbiting a small planet (or sometimes another small object in the solar system). The solar system has six planetary satellite systems, including 205 known natural satellites. The International Astronomical Union (IAU) has a schedule of four dwarf planets known to have natural satellites: Pluto, Haumea, Makemaki and Iris. By September 2018, there were 334 known small planets with moons. The Earth's system is unique betweplanetary systems in terms of the ratio betwethe moon's mass and the Earth's mass, which is larger than any ratio betwea natural moon and a planet in the solar system. The diameter of the moon is 3,474 kilometres (2,158 miles), which is 0.273 times the diameter of the Earth. This ratio is five times higher betwethe diameter of a satellite and the diameter of its planet (the ratio betwethe diameter of Neptune and the country of the largest satellite 0.055, the ratio betwethe diameter of Saturn and the diameter of its largest satellite 0.044, the ratio betwethe diameter of Jupiter and the country of its largest satellite 0.038, and the ratio betwethe diameter of Uranus and the diameter of its largest satellite 0.031). Turning to small planets, of the five known planets in the solar system, the Moon has the largest share, with the ratio betweits diameter and Pluto's diameter being half (0.52). The first known natural moon was the Moon (Earth Moon or Moon), but it was considered a planet until Copernicus' forehead appeared in the book in the orbits of planets in 1543. There was no chance of referring to objects like this in a single category until Galileo's moons were discovered in 1610. Galileo chose to refer to his discoveries as planets, but later explorers chose other terms to distinguish them from orbital objects. The German astronomer Johannes Kepler was the first to use the term Moon/Satellite to describe orbital objects in the Jupiter's Four Observed Moon Tale Book in 1610.

Radar is a system that uses electromagnetic waves to identify the distance, height, direction and speed of fixed and mobile objects, such as aircraft, ships, vehicles, weather and terrain. The transmitter sends radio waves reflected by the target and is identified by the receiver. The wave to the future is weak, and the receiver inflates those waves, which makes it easier for the monitors to distinguish the wave from other waves, such as sound waves and light waves. Disclosures are used in many areas, such as meteorology, to determine the timing of rainfall and aerial surveillance and by the police to detect excess speed, and finally and most importantly military use. The radar is called Radio Detection And Ranging, meaning radiowave detection and Range. The first to use radio waves to detect the presence of remote metal objects was the German scientist Christian Holsmeyer, who revealed the presence of a ship in the fog but without specifying the distance in 1904. Nicola Tesla, a pioneer in electricity science, created the foundations betwethe waves and the energy level prior to the Second World War, namely, in August 1917, which was the primary screen. Yel'Girardo, who invented the first French screener, according to Tesla's basic perceptions, while the first full screwas in Britain, where he developed as an early warning tool for any hostile aircraft attack, in 1935. During the Second World War, the proportion of research increased with a view to inventing the best reagents as defensive techniques, until mobile detectors appeared with better specifications. Irbid is a Jordanian city, the centre of Irbid governorate in northern Jordan and its largest city. It is located 71 kilometres north of the capital, Amman, and approximately 20 kilometres south of the Syrian-Jordanian border. It is the third largest city in the Kingdom after the capital city of Jordan and Zarqa in terms of its population. The population of the city and its suburbs is estimated to be over 555,000, according to the 2019 census. The area of the city with its suburbs is estimated to be approximately 30 square kilometres. The location of the city of Irbid is considered to be medium for the rest of the governorate; it is located at a 32-N latitude and 35-E longitude radius. The geographical nature of the city is easy, although the western regions are more mountainous in nature. Its beginnings were in the Roman era, where it was built at a middle site among the 10 historic cities of the Dekapolis Alliance, and later became a centre of Islamic conquest, with one of the largest libraries in the Middle East, the Husseini Library at Yarmouk University. In another novel, the origin of the name Arabella is a Roman word that means "black," and the Romans have changed its name to Arbela, the name that is similar to the Greek name: Arabella, and the word "rapella" means fertile land. It is also said that its current name is only a distortion of the name of the old Roman town of Beth Arbel, or a term derived from the word " butter "; this is due to the colour of the red earth soil accompanied by volcanic rock pads scattered around the city.

Since the Renaissance, the European continent has had a major impact on the world's culture, economy and social movements. Most of the inventions in the Western world originate primarily from Europe and the United States. From the 15th century onwards, the continent's population began to grow steadily, peaking in the 19th century following the industrial revolution. In this century, the continent ' s population has doubled from 187 million to 401 million. This increase was one of the results of the industrial revolution, which brought about technical, economic and social changes that led to tangible improvement in all spheres of life on the continent. During the years of World War I and II (1914-1945), nearly 70 million Europeans died as a result of war, violence and famine. As the continent's standard of living increased after the years of war, it led to a decline in the birth rate and a rise in the population's ageing, and was thus called the old continent at present. In 2005, United Nations statistics estimated Europe ' s population at around 731,000 million, more than 9% of the world ' s population. A century ago, Europe had about a quarter of the world ' s population. Population growth in Europe has beslower than in other regions of the world (especially in Africa and Asia), where the population has grown more rapidly. Europe is one of the continents with relatively high population density and is second to Asia.
